step.context: %text Let us begin from the inside and make our way out. What is $\sin(\cot^{-1}x)$? %
step.reason: %text If $\cot^{-1}x=\theta$, it implies $x=\cot\theta$. Therefore, the ratio of the opposite side of the Right triangle to the adjacent side is $x:1$. Therefore the $\sin$ (opp/hyp) of the same angle is given by $\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^2}}$. % \sin\theta=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^2}}\implies \theta=\sin^{-1}\left(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^2}}\right) \\ \begin{align} \therefore \sin(\cot^{-1}x)&=\sin\theta \\ &=\sin \left(\sin^{-1}\left(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^2}}\right)\right) \\ &=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1+x^2}} \end{align}

%text If $\tan^{-1}y=\phi$, it implies $y=\tan\phi$. Therefore, the ratio of the opposite side of the Right triangle to the adjacent side is $y:1$. Therefore the $\cos$ (adj/hyp) of the same angle is given by $\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1+y^2}}$. % \cos\phi=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1+y^2}}\implies \phi=\cos^{-1}\left(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1+y^2}}\right) \\ \begin{align} \therefore \cos\left(\tan^{-1}y\right)&=\cos\phi \\ &=\cos \left(\cos^{-1}\left(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1+y^2}}\right)\right) \\ &=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1+y^2}} \end{align}
